--- title: "about" image: icon/do-not-save-me.jpg about: template: solana links: - icon: twitter text: Twitter href: https://twitter.com/vvsuschevskiy target: _blank - icon: linkedin text: LinkedIn href: https://www.linkedin.com/in/vvsuschevskiy/ target: _blank - icon: github text: Github href: https://github.com/vvseva target: _blank --- ### Please call me Seva; here is my [CV](cv/cv_page.html). ::: {#hero-heading} In general, I like what Computational Social Science claims to be, especially inferring human behaviour either with Agent-Based Modeling and/or virtual labs (a.k.a. digital experiments), where networks serve as a computational representation of a social structure . ## Bio In Summer 2022, I joined [Technology and Social Behaviour](https://tsb.northwestern.edu/) at Northwestern University where I work as a research assistant at [SONIC](http://sonic.northwestern.edu/). I use social network analysis models to understand mechanism of interaction and communication in human-AI teams. Before that, I worked as a research assistant at [Universitetet i Bergen](https://www.uib.no/en/persons/Vsevolod.Suschevskiy). Together with Mohammad Khalil at [SLATE](https://slate.uib.no/), we created CERES – a virtuall lab to study course recommendation system. We even published a [paper](https://www.researchgate.net/publication/350874550_Creating_a_Course_Recommendation_System_for_Exchange_Students) about the first iteration, but we also managed to launch and analyze a pilot experiment with real students. Furthermore, I worked on analyzing classroom intervention with mixed models and SEMs. *(one day it will be published)* Also, I was a moderate [Computer’ish Science](https://spb.hse.ru/en/ma/computer/) student at HSE University. I worked with Ilya Musabirov, and my thesis reacived a research grant from Toloka to explore the effect of self nudges on motivation. Last, but not for the amount of time it required, I worked as (1) an invited lecturer at [Data Science minor](https://electives.hse.ru/minor_data_spb/) at the same HSE University. The course was mostly a mix of CSS and intro to data science for 200 non-STEM students, so we are talking about *tidyverse*, *tidymodels*, and *shiny*. In addition, (2) an invited lecturer for a graduate-level course – Into to Small Data Science for Political Science students. And (3) an invited co-lecturer for a Data Visualization course with [Anastasia Kuznetsova](https://t.me/nastengraph) at [European University at St. Petersburg](https://eusp.org/programs/applied-data-analysis). *(At some point, some materials will be available at ...)* ::: ### Test of visnetwork ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} require(visNetwork, quietly = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` Warning: package 'visNetwork' was built under R version 4.3.3 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # minimal example nodes <- data.frame(id = 1:3) edges <- data.frame(from = c(1,2), to = c(1,3)) visNetwork(nodes, edges, width = "100%") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: :::
